title: [BUG] Loading a custom pyfunc model that loads another model in its load_context()
body:
Thank you for submitting an issue. Please refer to our [issue policy](https://www.github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/master/ISSUE_POLICY.md) for additional information about bug reports. For help with debugging your code, please refer to [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/mlflow).

**Please fill in this bug report template to ensure a timely and thorough response.**

### Willingness to contribute
The MLflow Community encourages bug fix contributions. Would you or another member of your organization be willing to contribute a fix for this bug to the MLflow code base?

- [ ] Yes. I can contribute a fix for this bug independently.
- [ ] Yes. I would be willing to contribute a fix for this bug with guidance from the MLflow community.
- [x] No. I cannot contribute a bug fix at this time.

### System information
- **Have I written custom code (as opposed to using a stock example script provided in MLflow)**: Yes
- **OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04)**: Databricks
- **MLflow installed from (source or binary)**: Databricks
- **MLflow version (run ``mlflow --version``)**: 1.1.13
- **Python version**: 3.7
- **npm version, if running the dev UI**:
- **Exact command to reproduce**:

### Describe the problem
If I log two models, even for different runs, and if one of them is a pyfunc model that loads the other in its load_context(), the pyfunc.load_model fails with 'TypeError: load_context() got multiple values for argument 'context''

### Code to reproduce issue
```python
from mlflow.pyfunc import PythonModel
class ExtendedPythonModel(PythonModel):
  
    def __init__(self, keras_model_name, tokenizer, labels, max_sequence_length):
        self.keras_model_name = keras_model_name
        self.tokenizer = tokenizer
        self.labels = labels
        self.max_sequence_length = max_sequence_length
        
    def load_context(context):
        self.keras_model = mlflow.keras.load_model(model_uri=context.artifacts[self.keras_model_name], compile=False)
        
    def predict(self, context, model_input):
        tokenizedText = self.tokenizer.texts_to_sequences(model_input)
        paddedSequence = pad_sequences(tokenizedText, maxlen=self.max_sequence_length)

        pred = self.keras_model.predict_classes(paddedSequence)
        result = [self.labels[i] for i in pred]
        return result

with mlflow.start_run():
    mlflow.keras.log_model(model, artifact_path="keras")
    run_id = mlflow.active_run().info.run_id
    

with mlflow.start_run():
    extendedModel = ExtendedPythonModel("keras_model", tokenizer, labels, 25)
    mlflow.pyfunc.log_model(python_model=extendedModel, artifact_path="model", artifacts={"keras_model":f"runs:/{run_id}/keras"})

modelLoaded = mlflow.pyfunc.load_model(model_uri="runs:/14ae74ae60274d8awww9a42048c864ca/model")
modelLoaded
TypeError: load_context() got multiple values for argument 'context'
```
### Other info / logs

TypeError: load_context() got multiple values for argument 'context'
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<command-1460123932475733> in <module>
----> 1 modelLoaded = mlflow.pyfunc.load_model(model_uri="runs:/14ae74ae60274d8a9d69a42048c864ca/model")
      2 modelLoaded

/databricks/python/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mlflow/pyfunc/__init__.py in load_model(model_uri, suppress_warnings)
    464         mlflow.pyfunc.utils._add_code_to_system_path(code_path=code_path)
    465     data_path = os.path.join(local_path, conf[DATA]) if (DATA in conf) else local_path
--> 466     model_impl = importlib.import_module(conf[MAIN])._load_pyfunc(data_path)
    467     return PyFuncModel(model_meta=model_meta, model_impl=model_impl)
    468 

/databricks/python/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mlflow/pyfunc/model.py in _load_pyfunc(model_path)
    216 
    217     context = PythonModelContext(artifacts=artifacts)
--> 218     python_model.load_context(context=context)
    219     return _PythonModelPyfuncWrapper(python_model=python_model, context=context)
    220 

TypeError: load_context() got multiple values for argument 'context'

### What component(s), interfaces, languages, and integrations does this bug affect?
Components 
- [x] `area/artifacts`: Artifact stores and artifact logging
- [ ] `area/build`: Build and test infrastructure for MLflow

- [ ] `area/projects`: MLproject format, project running backends
- [ ] `area/scoring`: Local serving, model deployment tools, spark UDFs
- [ ] `area/server-infra`: MLflow server, JavaScript dev server
- [ ] `area/tracking`: Tracking Service, tracking client APIs, autologging

Interface 
- [ ] `area/uiux`: Front-end, user experience, JavaScript, plotting
- [ ] `area/docker`: Docker use across MLflow's components, such as MLflow Projects and MLflow Models
- [ ] `area/sqlalchemy`: Use of SQLAlchemy in the Tracking Service or Model Registry
- [ ] `area/windows`: Windows support

Language 
- [ ] `language/r`: R APIs and clients
- [ ] `language/java`: Java APIs and clients
- [ ] `language/new`: Proposals for new client languages

Integrations
- [ ] `integrations/azure`: Azure and Azure ML integrations

- [ ] `integrations/databricks`: Databricks integrations
